summary:
Making the world a better place through the art of story telling. That is my mission as a photographer. Creating unique compelling visual stories relevant to society; raising awareness and stimulate participation. Stories shown from the perspective of those directly involved contributing to new perspectives, ideas and possible solutions focussing on participation and involvement of the audience.  

I can help you find and tell your story:
Starting with the strategic setup followed by content creation. Together with a team of leading experts in their field. 

For more information call or email me:
 cynthia@cynthiaboll.nl | 0650634796 | www.cynthiaboll.com

treasury_media.title: the Dyke, social impact stories of a Dutch icon
treasury_media.description: Dijken en dammen beschermen Nederland tegen natte voeten. In het land van de Deltawerken is de Afsluitdijk een fascinerend waterbouwkundig icoon. Het beschermt en verbindt Nederland Nederland bijna negentig jaar. Nu wordt de dijk gerenoveerd. Welke verandering zet dat in gang? En wat betekent dit voor de toekomst van Nederland? In een serie van zes verhalen schetst the Dyke een portret van een land in verandering, hoe Nederlanders zich daarin bewegen en de rol van een dijk in deze transitie.

projects.title: Break out session What Design Can Do Mexico City
projects.description:
JOIN FORCES AND ESTABLISH NEW IDEAS ON HOW TO RAISE AWARENESS ABOUT SINKING CITIES
Hosted by Kummer & Herrman and Cynthia Boll Photography
The challenge in this breakout session is to come up with new ideas connecting science and design in relation to sinking cities. México City is currently sinking, subsiding as much as 38 cm / 15 inches per year. A relatively unknown phenomenon, this issue needs design power to raise more awareness.

projects.title: Bij de Chinees
Sinking Cities, Jakarta
projects.description: Sinking Cities, Jakarta a photo and multimedia exhibition Erasmus Huis Jakarta

projects.title: Communication campaign Building with Nature program
projects.description:
In Northern Java communities are suffering from coastal erosion along hundreds of kilometers of coastline. In the district of Demak more than 3 km of land have already been swallowed by the sea including entire villages. Sea level rise is projected to flood 6 kilometers inland by 2100, affecting over 70,000 people and 6000 hectares of aquaculture ponds. In the long run 30 million people may suffer from coastal erosion. The main causes of the erosion problems are the removal of mangrove belts for aquaculture development, coastal infrastructure which disturbs sediment build up from offshore, and groundwater extraction which causes land subsidence, and river canalization. The Building with Nature Indonesia Consortium introduces the Building with Nature approach to address these root causes, integrating mangrove and river restoration, small-scale engineering and sustainable land use. 

We helped the consortium: to develop a campaign strategy, research what is needed to mobilise stakeholders, visualise (pictures and interview) daily life in the communities and to guide the Building with Nature Consortium on how to continuate the campaign offline and through social media in the coming years (e.g. by enabling the team through capacity building to continue the activities themselves, and by advising how this can be embedded in the longer-term communications strategy.

projects.title: Banjir! Banjir! Living with water in Jakarta
projects.description: The book Banjir! Banjir! Living with water in Jakarta was published on Thursday 11 May as a token of gratitude to Henk Nieboer, who stepped down form the Witteveen + Bos Board of Directors.  The book shows 8 series of photographs demonstrating  water challenges Jakarta faces, interviews with leading experts and a foreword by Henk Nieboer.

contributors.headline: Manager business unit Digital Support bij Witteveen+Bos
Oprichter en eigenaar Schrijf-Schrijf, bureau voor communicatie en contentcreatie

projects.title: Jakarta Coastal Defence Strategy (NCICD)
projects.description:
Expert digital public communication outreach & tools for the consortium working on the master plan of the Jakarta Coastal Defence Strategy.

We assist & advised the Indonesian government on how to reach the coastal communities. 

The master plan addresses the recurring problem of severe flooding of the Jakarta metropolitan area due to fast and significant land subsidence and increased discharge of rivers. The project aims to provide a comprehensive flood protection strategy (and a concrete set of measures) for the short, medium and long term.

Utarakan Jakarta, The People Behind the Seawall'​

An awareness and information project on Jakarta is Sinking. Follow the stories of 4 people and their families in a 'Sinking Jakarta' on Facebook starting 1 October 2015

projects.title: The People Behind the Seawall, the exhibition
projects.description:
The exhibition ‘The People Behind the Seawall’ has opened at the Erasmus Huis in Jakarta, Indonesia and runs till May 13.  The exhibition focused on water-related challenges of families living in Northern Jakarta. The exhibition shows how four citizens and their families are dealing with water-related challenges, such as land subsidence, floods, heavy rainfall, waste, pollution and lack of drinking water. They live in Northern Jakarta, behind the current old seawall, where the threat of flooding is most severe. Photographer Cynthia Boll followed the lives of these four affected families and documented their personal stories.
The exhibition is an integrated part of Utarakan Jakarta  project.

projects.title: Zure Druiven (Sour Grapes)
projects.description:
South Africa is one of the largest wine-producing countries in the world. Exports have boomed over the last ten years, and have risen from 174 million litres in 2001 to 350 million in 2011. The Cape Winelands – the wine district of the Western Cape province – is one of the wealthiest areas of South Africa.

Over the last year there has been violant strikes and protests in South Africa by miners farmworkers, especially on vineyards. Prices of daily life have gone up considerably over the last year; bread, meat and petrol; The population revolts. Meet Johanna, 53 and seasonal farmworker in Stellenbosch area, the ‘wine capital’ of South Africa. An insight in the daily life of Johanna and her family during the height of the harvest time in Western Cape.

projects.title: Denk vooruit, kijk achterom
projects.description:
A serie about Ellen, a women diagnosed with bowl cancer. Despite her illness she lives her life as normal as possible.  

 'Denk vooruit, kijk achteruit'  a travelling exhibition. Initiative the Maag Lever Darm Stichting (MLDS) curated by Ben Krewinkel. 

The project has been published in a catalogue with the participating photographers; Cynthia Boll, Ringel Goslinga, Geert van Kesteren, Dana Lixenberg, Bertien van Manen.

The MLDS is an independent dutch foundation that tries to prevent and cure stomach, testine and liver diseases and to improve quality of life of patients. The MLDS is a facilitator of scientific research and is an information center that can be approached by individuals in search of specific knowledge and/or advice.

projects.title: 29 Minutes
projects.description:
In Afghanistan a woman dies during labour every 29 minutes.

A frightening statistic, this is one of the highest maternal death rates in the world. One of the most important causes of this is women’s poor accessibility to education and healthcare, and the lack of qualified midwives.

In the conservative city of Tarin Kowt (Uruzgan), a dedicated women’s wing was added to the provincial hospital in 2008. Women can go there for treatment, sex education and maternity care. There’s also a vaccination programme, and young women are trained to become midwife here. The Taliban considers women to be less than second-rate citizens. Although officially dispelled, the Taliban’s influence is still felt everywhere.

In traditional parts of Afghanistan – like Uruzgan – women only see very small improvements to their lives. Where women and girls are allowed to show themselves in public, they can only do so in the presence of their husband or a male relative, and they are required to wear a burqa. A visit to the women’s wing of the hospital is therefore not at all without risk. Being trained to become a midwife even less so. And still the women come. Still they finish their training and start their jobs. Despite their vulnerable position they have the drive and willpower to make a positive change in their lives.
Travelling Exhibition on maternal mortality in Afghanisthan.

courses.name: Magnum Photos, London | Professional Practice Seminar

profile_positions.description:
The scientific/documentary project Sinking Cities, will bridge the gap between personal experience and science, between policy and communities. The project will do that by forging an alliance between scientists and visual story tellers.Sinking Cities is a project with an open character. 

 Together with Deltares research institute and Kummer & Herrman creative agency we have joined forces for the ‘Sinking Cities’ project. Using our combined expertise, we demonstrate what land subsidence is, its impact on society and the resulting landscape, urban planning and political questions, choices and solutions to which it can lead. Using the personal stories of urban residents, the project illustrates the impact on the lives of those affected and their perspective on the future. What is it like to live in a sinking city? How do you deal with that reality? We connect this social reality with scientific research in an innovative and overarching way, drawing a multifaceted and engaging picture of the threat of land subsidence as well as the policy and technical options that exist to tackle it.
profile_positions.title: Sinking Cities, a global urban challenge

profile_positions.description:
I have extensive experience with long term photography & multimedia projects. From concept/ production/design/presentation (feature articles on and offline, exhibitions and book)
Creating unique compelling visual stories for both clients and for projects on my own initiative.

Making the world a better place through the art of story telling. That is my mission as a photographer. 

Over the recents years I have developed into an expert in visual storytelling & documentary projects. Combining photography with new technologies and forms of communication. New developments in photojournalism and media offer challenges and new opportunities: to tell a story in a new innovative way focusing on participation and involvement. 

Besides working on my own initiated projects I have worked for various news agencies such as Associated Press, ANP and GPD. Amongst others commissioned work for: Ministry of development cooperation, Ministry of foreign affairs, National Geographic Magazine, Algemeen Nederlands Persbureau, Associated Press, Marie Claire, Cordaid Memisa, The Telegraph Magazine.
profile_positions.title: Founder

profile_positions.description:
Sinking Cities - Gouda en het dalende land 
Een derde van ons land ligt beneden zeeniveau en Nederland is kampioen in het bouwen van dijken, dammen en stormvloedkeringen. Maar terwijl het stijgen van de zeespiegel alle aandacht krijgt, voltrekt zich aan de andere kant van de dijk iets wat veel minder bekend is: de bodem daalt. Op sommige plekken in West-Nederland is de bodem door de eeuwen heen vijf á tien meter gedaald. Als we doorgaan op de huidige voet, komen delen van de Randstad op acht á tien meter beneden NAP te liggen. 

De bodem daalt al duizend jaar. Maar door de klimaatverandering gaat het proces sneller dan verwacht en zijn de gevolgen groter. Bodemdaling zorgt voor funderingsproblemen, schade aan huizen en de infrastructuur en heeft negatieve gevolgen voor de landbouw, het klimaat, de natuur en de biodiversiteit.  

In Gouda merkt iedereen de gevolgen van de dalende bodem. Overal zakt wel iets weg: van de monumentale panden in de binnenstad en tuinen en straten in een woonwijk tot de koeien van de boeren in de omliggende polders. In hoeverre is de situatie in Gouda een voorbode voor de rest van Nederland? Betekent bodemdaling het einde van de historische binnensteden en het typisch Nederlandse polderlandschap? 

Sinking Cities Gouda gaat over die andere strijd van Nederlanders tegen het water. Over adaptatie, innovatie en vasthouden aan tradities. Over problemen én oplossingen. Een trilogie die begint in de historische binnenstad van Gouda en eindigt in de diepste polders van het land, de bakermat van de beroemde Goudse kaas. Wat betekent het om te wonen en te werken op een plek die zinkt onder je voeten?
profile_positions.title: Sinking Cities, Gouda

profile_positions.description:
the Dyke is a multimedia project about the future of the Netherlands. From Makkum to Amsterdam and Tzum, pioneers and game changers are working on solutions for the future. In the field of safety, energy, economy and ecology. And all those stories start with the Dyke.

The dike has been protecting and connecting the Netherlands for 90 years and is currently being renovated. What does this dike actually mean for the Netherlands? And for the Dutch we wondered. Who exactly is he protecting? And is that his only job?
I started this project together with journalist Stephanie Bakker to initiate a discussion about the implementation and design of large infrastructural projects with an eye for people and the environment. By sharing stories on our storytelling platform and through exhibitions, we want to start a conversation about this. Meet the people of the Dyke in six episodes at: www.the-dyke.com

'the Dyke' is an initiative of Cynthia Boll Photography and Laika Productions in collaboration with Van Oord.
profile_positions.title: the Dyke, social impact stories of a Dutch icon

profile_positions.description:
Utarakan Jakarta (Speak up! North Jakarta) is an awareness & information campaign about the sinking of Jakarta focussing on the urban young  in Jakarta. 
The project aims to inform and raise awareness about flooding in Jakarta. It also shows the urgency to protect Jakarta against floods. The project portrays the lives of 4 people living in North Jakarta behind the seawall. It captures their struggles with floods, a sinking house and the costs of drinking water in a city on the verge of drowning; their worries, dreams and hopes for a better future.  
Through various media platforms like Facebook, Twitter, website, magazines and exhibitions. The project can be followed  and on Facebook or website. 

I recruited and lead a team young Indonesian creatives for execution of this project. Such as a designer, social media experts, journalists, video editor & copywriter.

Background information
Jakarta, with around 20 million residents, making it one of the world’s five most densely populated cities, is on the verge of drowning. If nothing is done, it is expected one third of the city will be submerged in water in 20-30 years’ time. In some areas the city is sinking at an alarming rate of 7,5-25 cm a year caused by subsidence. Population growth and deep groundwater extraction are a big part of the problem. In the face of heavy rainfall disastrous floods are an impending situation for Jakarta. But also high river water levels because of water running down from the mountains and flooding due to obstruction and pollution of waterways. The risk of giant waves (tsunamis) and the rise of the sea level and a change of climate pose threats as well. Twenty percent of the residents of this megacity are poor and have no access to running water or sanitation. Jakarta relies on an existing 40-year-old seawall to keep the city safe from the Java Sea. This 30-kilometers seawall is also sinking at the same alarming rate.
profile_positions.title: Founder  'Utarakan Jakarta' (Speak up! North Jakarta)
